Colin,

These are excellent and insightful observations.  Have you 
considered getting a Ph.D? :P  Seriously, that is good research 
getting to the bottom of these questions.

I think your proposed changes to SharpNEAT make good sense.  I also 
do not kill off the top species, so I came to the same conclusion.  
But the idea of only adding a % of excess and disjoint genes I am 
unsure about.  If a complex of genes has formed that are all 
interdependent, that could be a bad move.  Maybe safer would be to 
just make adding *all* the excess and disjoint genes probabilistic.  

On the other hand, the real question of how to do it can only be 
addressed through comparisons of the types you've been doing, i.e. 
runs with one method vs. runs with another.  

In any case, the insight on fitness functions and how they affect 
complexity because of the idiosyncracies of my NEAT implementation 
are quite revealing.

It seems though that the most important conclusion so far is that 
phasing is a very good idea.  But it would be good to get more 
results backing that up so we can be confident about it.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Ok I've done some more experimenting and I'm starting to get some 
> answers now. Firstly, I stick by what I said previously...
> 
> Colin Green wrote:
> 
> >I still beleive 
> >that the drop in population fitness is due to the phenomena I 
described, 
> >that is:
> >
> >1) A rising species compatibilty threshold caused by the quickly 
rising 
> >complexity. This causes like species to be combined into fewer 
species.
> >
> >2) SharpNEAT culling fit species when they reach the drop off age.
> >
> >3) SharpNEATs current crossover technique which is very likely 
causing 
> >complexity to rise far quicker than in other NEAT implementations 
and 
> >thus exacerbating (1).
> >  
> >
> For brevity I'll refer to the two crossover techniques as, 
Original NEAT 
> crossover (Co) and Inclusive crossover (Ci). Ci being the 
technique that 
> SharpNEAT currently uses whereby the disjoint and excess genes are 
> always included from both parents, regardless of which is fittest. 
Kens 
> NEAT only does this when the parents have equal fitness.
> 
> I did some runs of my OCR domain. Witha complexifying run, when 
using Co 
> instead of Ci the complexity still rises in a roughly linear 
manner but 
> does so slower. The result is that the population fitness rises 
quickly 
> to about 100 and then maintains this level, perhaps with a slight 
drop 
> off (so very similar to the blended run graph in my write-up). A 
blended 
> run gave a similar profile but reaching a peak fitness of 120.
> 
> Ok so now consider that Derek's blended runs with ANJI/Tic-Tac-Toe 
> demonstrated a steady amount of complexity. Why is SharpNEAT 
showing a 
> steady rise but ANJI not?  The answer lies in the domains being 
used and 
> the fitness schemes used. I tried SharpNEAT with the TTT domain 
and Co, 
> the result was a steady amount of complexity, rising from a start 
value 
> of 10 to just 11.5 in 1000 generations.
> 
> Because TTT is non-determinstic the fitness values assigend to 
each 
> genome will almost always be different, even for very similar or 
> identical genomes. This means that the part of Co that includes 
genes 
> from both parents when their fitness is equal will hardly ever be 
> invoked. In contrast the OCR experiment only has 27 distinct 
fitness 
> values (0 to 260 in steps of  10) and within an evolving 
population most 
> of the genomes will have about the same fitness. This means that 
Co will 
> actually be performing inclusive crossover most of the time, which 
in 
> turn causes complexity to rise.
> 
> So OCR's fitness scheme causes the inclusive crossover to be 
invoked, 
> which in turn causes complexity to rise which  causes species to 
become 
> merged. The overall population fitness then drops when the few 
good 
> species are culled.
> 
> Hopefully this explains the discrepancies noted so far. It's 
interesting 
> that only a slight increase in the rate that complexity rises 
causes the 
> population fitness to drop off, but then this is tied to the 
species 
> culling age, the greater the age the greater the amount of 
tolerance 
> towards rising complexity. If you cross some threshold then the 
pop. 
> fitness will collapse.
> 
> In light of all this I'm going to make a few changes to SharpNEAT, 
#1 
> being the preservation of the fittest species. If  there are 
several 
> species with the maximum species then I will just cull them as 
normal, 
> so I only preserve the fittest species if is the only one. Yeh 
that 
> should work I think. By culling the fittest species I think I was 
trying 
> to achieve to much in the context of a single search, it's better 
to 
> allow the user to decide when a search has stagnated and needs 
> resetting. I suppose I could add in a new, 're-start age' 
parameter that 
> detects when the entire search has stagnated for some [large] # of 
> generations and resets the population.
> 
> I also think that getting crossover to include genes from both 
parents 
> more often would be a good thing. Though perhaps not the 100% 
inclusive 
> scheme I've been using up until now, perhaps 10% of the genes from 
the 
> weakest parent and I'll parameterize this value.
> 
> Colin.
